page:
Dependent Pronouns Be sure to include as dependent pronouns here all affixes that attach to nouns to agree with or express the possessor and those that attach to verbs to agree with the subject or object. Your language may not have dependent forms for all the same sets as the independent pronouns. In that case, leave them blank here and plan to remove the extra sets with the appropriate explanation when you edit the grammar output.
RPronDependent Does your language also have sets of dependent pronouns? No, only independent pronouns Yes, there are also dependent pronoun forms which attach to verbs and possibly nouns or other words
WARNING: You said above that your language does not have dependent pronouns, but you said in
Nominal Phrases - Possessor Agreement that nouns are marked with an affix that agrees with or expresses the possessor. Those affixes should be added in this section as dependent pronouns for the possessor. Please change your answer above to "Yes" so you will be able to add the dependent pronouns for possessors and possibly for others with agree with the subject, etc.
Where do the dependent pronouns attach to the verb or noun or other words? Check all options that are correct for your language As a proclitic which attaches to the beginning of whatever word begins the verb phrase or nominal phrase As an enclitic which attaches to the end of whatever word ends the verb phrase or nominal phrase As a prefix which attaches to the verb or noun As a suffix which attaches to the verb or noun In my language, these elements may attach as follows:
WARNING: You need to check at least one box to describe how these dependent pronouns attach in your language, or change the answer above to ‘No, only independent pronouns’.
RPronDepClassifierAgr Are the dependent pronouns the same as the noun class markers for specific classes? No, the dependent pronouns are distinct from the noun class markers Yes, the dependent pronouns are either identical or closely related to the appropriate noun class markers
Since your language does not distinguish case, you should have only a single set of dependent pronouns that can be used in any position in the sentence.
Since your language does not distinguish case, you should have a single set of dependent pronouns that can be used in any position in the sentence, plus an additional set which are used as subjects of verbs which have an Experiencer subject, rather than an Agent subject. The first set is for Agent subjects.
Key the dependent first person singular pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent first person plural pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent first person plural exclusive pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent first person plural inclusive pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent second person singular pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent second person plural pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent third person singular pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent third person plural pronouns in the text box.
This second set is for Experiencer subjects.
Key the dependent first person singular pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent first person plural pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent first person plural exclusive pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent first person plural inclusive pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent second person singular pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent second person plural pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent third person singular pronouns in the text box.
Key the dependent third person plural pronouns in the text box.
In the lexicon, add the feature dative to all the pronouns that occur as Experiencer subjects.
Since your language has a nominative-accusative case system, you should have distinct sets of dependent pronouns that are normally used to serve as or agree with subjects, objects, and possessors. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said that your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject as for verbs which have an subject. We will allow for an additional set of pronouns for indirect objects. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said that your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject as for the objects of verbs which have an subject. We will allow for an additional set of pronouns for indirect objects. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said that your language uses a distinct set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject from either the subjects or objects of verbs which have an subject. We will assume the pronouns which can be used for indirect objects are the ones which express the subjects of Experiencer verbs and will ask you for an additional set of pronouns.
Key the dependent first person singular pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects in the text box.

Key the dependent first person plural exclusive pronouns which can appear as subjects in the text box.

In the lexicon:
Add the feature nominative to all the pronouns that occur as Agent subjects.
Add the feature accusative.or.dative to all the pronouns that can occur as objects and indirect objects and Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature accusative to all the pronouns that occur as objects.
Add the feature dative to all the pronouns that occur as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature genitive to all the pronouns that occur as possessors.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: accusative.or.dative, accusative.or.genitive, accusative.or.nominative, dative.or.genitive, dative.or.nominative, nominative.or.genitive or -accusative (for all but accusative case), -dative, -genitive or -nominative.
If a particular pronoun can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
Since your language has an ergative-absolutive case system, you should have distinct sets of dependent pronouns that can be used as subjects of transitive verbs versus subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject as for verbs which have an subject. We will allow for an additional set of pronouns for indirect objects. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject as for the objects of verbs which have an subject. We will allow for an additional set of pronouns for indirect objects. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said your language uses a distinct set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject from either the subjects or objects of verbs which have an subject. We will assume the pronouns which can be used for indirect objects are the ones which express the subjects of Experiencer verbs and will ask you for an additional set of pronouns.
Key the dependent first person singular pronouns which can appear as Agent subjects of transitive verbs in the text box.

Key the dependent third person plural pronouns which can appear as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects in the text box.
In the lexicon:
Add the feature ergative to all the pronouns that occur as Agent subjects of transitive verbs.
Add the feature absolutive.or.dative to all the pronouns that occur as objects or indirect objects of transitive verbs and as subjects of intransitive verbs.
Add the feature absolutive to all the pronouns that occur as objects of transitive verbs and as Agent subjects of intransitive verbs.
Add the feature dative to all the pronouns that occur as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature genitive
ergative
absolutive to all the pronouns that occur as possessors.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: absolutive.or.dative, absolutive.or.ergative or ergative.or.dative.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: absolutive.or.dative, absolutive.or.genitive, absolutive.or.ergative, dative.or.genitive, dative.or.ergative, ergative.or.genitive or -absolutive (for all but absolutive case), -dative, -genitive or -ergative.
If a particular pronoun can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
Since your language has a split case system, you should have distinct sets of dependent pronouns that are normally used as subjects, objects, and possessors, plus some special sets which are used in the split ergativity cases. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject as for verbs which have an subject. We will allow for an additional set of pronouns for indirect objects. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said your language uses the same set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject as for the objects of verbs which have an subject. We will allow for an additional set of pronouns for indirect objetcs. In
Overall Typology Questions - Case System, you said your language uses a distinct set of pronouns for subjects of verbs which have an subject from either the subjects or objects of verbs which have an subject. We will assume the pronouns which can be used for indirect objects are the ones which express the subjects of Experiencer verbs and will ask you for an additional set of pronouns.

Key the dependent third person singular pronouns which appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box.
Key the dependent third person plural pronouns which appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs in the special cases of split ergativity in the text box.
In the lexicon:
Add the feature nominative to all the pronouns that occur as Agent subjects.
Add the feature accusative.or.dative to all the pronouns that can occur as objects and indirect objects and Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature accusative to all the pronouns that occur as objects.
Add the feature dative to all the pronouns that occur as indirect objects or as Experiencer subjects.
Add the feature genitive to all the pronouns that occur as possessors.
If a particular pronoun can occur in more than one position, but not all, you have the choice of making separate lexical entries or choosing the appropriate feature combination from those given here: accusative.or.dative, accusative.or.genitive, accusative.or.nominative, dative.or.genitive, dative.or.nominative, nominative.or.genitive or -accusative (for all but accusative case), -dative, -genitive or -nominative.
If a particular pronoun can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
For the split ergativity cases, add the feature ergative to all the pronouns that can only occur as subjects of transitive verbs and add the feature absolutive to all the pronouns that can only occur as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs. Note that if there is some overlap between the pronoun sets for nominative-accusative versus ergative-absolutive, you will probably need to have two entries in your lexicon for those pronouns, each marked with the appropriate case feature.
Add the relevant agreement features to each pronoun in the lexicon.
Person features: first, first_exclusive, first_inclusive, second or third
Number features: singular, dual or plural
Gender features: masculine, feminine or neuter
Animacy features: animate, -animate, human or -human
. If a pronoun is not specified for a particular type of agreement feature, do not add any feature of that type. Note that the dependent pronoun forms need additional features for their use as possessors when attached to nouns, which should have been added in
Nominal Phrases - Possessor Agreement, The dependent pronoun forms will also need additional features for their use as agreement when attached to verbs. These will be added in
Basic Sentences - Agreement Features.
&TechnicalTerms;
